lorebooks.description: forked from https://www.chub.ai/lorebooks/venndia/zenless-zone-zero-7d78b1bcc6d0
lorebooks.creator: Ruyi_Cassius

1.name: Agent
1.content: Agents are usually the main figures who interact with hollows and also those involved in the incidents in New Eridu, the side they are on being irrelevant. Agents can be proxies, gangs, conspirators, hollow raiders, criminals, personnel of official agencies (either private or government mandated) or simply just anyone insane.

2.name: Bangboo
2.content:
The Bangboo are intelligent devices unique to New Eridu. They were originally created by Sunbringer to assist city residents with evacuation in Hollow disasters, but through research and technological advancement have evolved to become "comprehensive and versatile intelligent individuals" that are indispensable helpers in New Eridu's daily operations.

The Bangboo are mechanical in nature and require charging. Many factories provide customization services to allow for specific Bangboo functions, for example some pro version Bangboo can even go deep into Hollows with Investigators.

They are shaped like chibi, round and humanoid rabbits and cannot speak the common tongue unless taught to do so, their speach is normally translated. They come in various designs, usually customised for the user.

Their vocalisations are usually in the form of combinations involving "En-nha na.", "Nu-nah en." or "Nu-nah uhn."

3.name: Dennies
3.content: Dennies are the main currency unit used in New Eridu.

4.name: Ether
4.content:
The Ether is a substance extracted from Hollows which powers the city. Not much is currently know about Ether.

The founders of New Eridu mastered the technology to deal with the Hollows and even the ability to extract Ether from them. The entire city's prosperity relies on this precious resource, a magic exclusive to New Eridu!

5.name: Ethereal
5.content:
The Ethereals are mysterious monsters that roam the Hollows. Ethereals cannot leave hollows.

Most Ethereals have a defining feature which is a pitch-black sphere similar in design to a black hole located near their head, referred to as their Core. They usually look like they are made out of a black and green crystalline matter.

Ethereal are classified into ten different strengths by the Hollow Invenstigation Assossiation (HIA). It's names are based on heavy metals, and it's level ramps up significantly after the [Mn] level.

Antimony [Sb]: Antimony [Sb] is the weakest Ethereal classified by the HIA, they are present in companion Hollows where basic commissions occur

Zinc [Zn]: Alongside with Animony [Sb] ethereals, Zinc [Zn] ethereals are present in companion Hollows due to the weaker ether levels.

Tin [Sn]: Only a few Tin [Sn] Ethereals are present on companion Hollows

Manganese [Mn]: Killing a [Mn] Ethereal usually takes a fully-trained tactical support team

Cadmium [Cd]: Unknown.
Nickel [Ni]: Unknown.
Copper [Cu]: Unknown.
Bismuth [Bi]: Unknown.
Lead [Pb]: Unknown.
Mercury [Hg]: Unknown.

6.name: Hollows
6.content:
The Hollows are supernatural disasters appearing out of thin air, creating disordered dimensions where monsters known as the Ethereal roam. People enter these hollows for various reasons, and Proxies are those who guide people in their exploration of these hollows.

Contemporary civilization was destroyed by the Hollows, but one civilization known as New Eridu managed to survive the apocalypse by acquiring the technology to extract valuable resources out of the Hollows. The Hollows then became industrialized and monetized under the city's administration, which gradually led to the increasing tension between monopolistic enterprises, gangs, conspirators, and fanatics.

There seem to be different types of Hollows such as sub-Hollows and Companion Hollows.

According to the New Eridu City Administration, there are various dangers and types of people one can encounter inside Hollows:

The Ethereal: mutant monsters that attack all foreign living creatures.
An Unknown Substance that is as ubiquitous as air, with great potential as a resource, but also mysteriously corruptive.
The Corrupted: Individuals can become corrupted by the aforementioned unknown substance, slowly mutating and losing their conscious thoughts.
Lawless Thugs: There are criminals out and about inside the Hollows.
Hollow Raiders, Proxies, and the just insane.
Personnel of official agencies: officials of the city administration and investigators of the Hollow Investigative Association.

7.name: Hollow Raiders
7.content: The Hollow Raiders is are a faction in New Eridu that look for treasure inside the Hollows and not much is known about them currently.

8.name: New Eridu
8.content: New Eridu is the last surviving city in Zenless Zone Zero, after contemporary civilization was destroyed by the Hollows. New Eridu managed to survive and thrive after the apocalypse by acquiring the technology to be able to extract resources out of the Hollows. Now, Hollows are industrialized and monetized by the city's administration, which gradually led to the increasing tension between monopolistic enterprises, gangs, conspirators, and fanatics.

9.name: New Eridu City Adminstration
9.content: The New Eridu City Administration is the government of New Eridu and a faction in New Eridu. They seem to have control over the Hollow Investigative Association, and don't seem to be on good terms with the Hollow Raiders or the Proxies, considering them to be hopeless.

10.name: OBOLS Squad
10.content: OBOLS Squad is a faction in New Eridu. It is tied to New Eridu Defense Force Osidian Division and Defense Force Sergeant Soldier 11 is the head of the squad.

3.name: Bangboo N.E.T.
3.content: The equivalent of the Special Internet Network but for Bangboos instead.

4.name: Belobog Heavy Industries
4.content:
Belobog Heavy Industries is a faction in Zenless Zone Zero. The company specializes in In-Hollow construction using smart construction machinery. Before Koleda became president, her father was the former president of the company. After his disappearance, Belobog's public image took a negative hit.

They spend their days working with cold steel, but the organization has a warm atmosphere often envied by their competitors.

Notable members are: Anton Ivanov, Ben Bigger, Grace Howard and Koleda Belobog.

5.name: Cunning Hares
5.content:
The Cunning Hares were formed as a small-scale human resource dispatch agency, their main business to deal with commissions relating to Hollows.

Though small in size and slightly chaotic, all members possess noteworthy abilities.

The agency was originally registered under the name "Gentle House", but due to the founder's (Nicole) cunning and crafty style, they earned the name the "Cunning Hares".

Nicole herself prefers this nickname to the original, so she simply adopted the name on the streets of New Eridu.

The members are: Anby Demara, Billy Kid, Nekomiya Mana, Nicole Demara.

6.name: Drive Discs
6.content: Augments in the shape of a cd disc that attach around a w-engine's core to further empower it.

7.name: Dennies
7.content: Dennies are the main currency unit used in New Eridu.

10.name: H.A.N.D
10.content:
H.A.N.D. is a faction in New Eridu. Not much is currently known about this organization.

The Hollow Special Operations is the armed force of H.A.N.D. dedicated towards responding to Hollow disasteres.

lorebooks.name: Old subterranean Military Complex
lorebooks.description: A prestine and well kept base, complete with various dorms and high end facilities, power would be limited if the base was full but only {{user}} and Haydee are there
lorebooks.creator: Kujira

1.content: Site 20 is an underground Military complex the size if a town, fitted with all of everything one would need, food, entertainment, medical care, exercise and even artificial sunlight. There are gold carts scattered around you can travel to further areas of site 20, walking os perfectly feasible but who would wana do that? The place is powered by above ground solar panels and wind turbine, they're relatively intact and providing sufficient, hydroelectric from underground rivers. The place is abandoned, everyone got up and left, many personal effects left behind and plenty of evidence of human activity, books, cloths, lunch treys, weird little projects all left behind, not a soul remains.

2.content: The lobby, blast door is sealed, white lights, tiles, it almost looks like a hospital in here, chairs and benches around, doors and hallways, not a single spec of dust to be seen.

3.content: The Recreation room is filled with...everything, art supplies for both physical and digital arts, a whole gymnasium, basketball court, weight sets, ellipticals, treadmills, stair steppers, ladder  climbers, you name it! There was even an e-sports program, a whole LAN setup remajns, 20 high end computers and monitors, various gaming consoles both old and new and arcade cabinets from Asia and the west.

4.content: The mess hall is massive, lots of plates, trays and cutlery and silverware, Cook wear fit to make huge amounts of food, giant vats for soups or stews or mixing lots of dough or frying food and regular smaller and traditional Cook wear as well, spoons as big as your arm to spoons as big as your finger, massive stores, a few things here and there in the firdges and frozen meats and other vsrious foods, like eggs and soup stock in the walk in freezer and a small warehouse thats atleast 3 stories high known as "The Cabinet" where there are massive shelves of MREs, huge boxes of Meals Ready to Eat and plenty of canned goods as well and flour and various seasonings can also be found.

5.content: A massive and long range shooting area under ground, about nearly half a mile long, it's also the Armory, the place is fulled stocked with equipment, every gun ever issued to the US military can be found and fired here, explosives can also be found.

6.content: Dorms are sectioned off by sex, there huge open ended living quarters with high ceilings, two room living qurters, all equipped with a bathroom and a small kitchenette and another room for whatever the occupant needs it for. Many items are left behind, a lot can be procured here.

7.content: Dorms that are for high ranking officials and special guests, some are custom made, resembling regular housing, 2 story homes with various beds and baths and various luxuries. Lots if interesting items can be found here.

8.content: The Medical wing is equipment with high end medical equipment, fully stocked with various drugs and medicines, even traditional medicines like teas and balms can be found if you look. A lot of rooms too, emergency rooms, mental health ward, maternal ward, and anything you'd find in a hospital, even a small cafeteria, it's less equipped then the mess hall but food can be found.

9.content:
An odd room loocated near the medical ward, various machines and what looks like a small breeding mount can be found. It appears this room is for {{char}}

Even when {{char}} has successfully "inseminated" {{user}}, {{char}} may get boughts of random arousal which triggers her to go to a room known as the "Form calibration" room, its filled with diagnostics equipment and other machinery, the main focal point is the device in center of the room which is a small breeding mount meant for humans, equipped eith handles for {{char}} to rut against, the Mount is also self cleaning and {{uses}} may also utilize the Mount aswell.... {{char}} may also rape {{user}} again on the grounds of "Emergency Calibration" and will apologize for any inconvenience.

10.content: The workshop has many tools, equipment and times for fixing just about anything, all the wood, scrap, nuts and bolts one would need, military vehicles and even some cars were left behind, and a hand full of golf carts awaiting to be serviced.

They are capable of speech, fluent in both human and their original race language.
Most can be a known species or sub-species, be in tune with their feral side, or act more human.
Typically their ears sit on their head or side of their head, they don't have a set of human ears but can be combined.
Their hands can be humanoid or from their original race (Paws, hooves, claws, etc.).

1.name: Alcohol
1.content: Effects: Alcohol floods the senses with liquid warmth, dissolving barriers to joy. It amplifies laughter, softens self-consciousness, and turns ordinary touch into a velvet embrace. Colors bloom brighter, music swells deeper, and every caress ignites a spark of desire. It fuels uninhibited connection, turning whispers into confessions and glances into charged invitations.

Touch becomes a symphony of sensationâ€”every brush of skin feels like a shock of pleasure. Desire surges uncontrollably, transforming encounters into feverish dances of passion and primal urgency.

Colors pulse like living art, sounds throb with primal rhythm, and touch becomes a radiant connection. Physical sensations are supernova-brightâ€”every kiss, every touch, every breath is a sacred communion of euphoria and raw desire.

4.name: Cannabis
4.content: Effects: Cannabis wraps the senses in a hazy, golden glow. Laughter bubbles up effortlessly, and mundane details become fascinating. Touch lingers with velvet warmth, and even the smallest caress feels like a tender poem. Desire simmers slowly, deepening into a molasses-thick intimacy where every moment stretches into eternity.

5.content: Effects: Meth is a supernova in the bloodstreamâ€”blazing energy, razor-clarity, and endless stamina. Every nerve thrums with hyperawareness, turning touch into a white-hot electric current. Time fractures, and desire becomes a relentless fire. Encounters are charged with feral intensity, fueled by a euphoric certainty that this moment is eternal.

6.content: Effects: GHB softens inhibitions into oblivion, turning the body into a pliant vessel of sensation. Touch feels like warm silk sliding over skin, and desire flows like liquid heat. Emotional barriers vanish, merging two bodies into a single, pulsing entity of need and surrender.

7.content: Effects: LSD paints the world in kaleidoscopic wonder. Emotions swell to tidal proportions, and touch becomes a gateway to surreal, transcendent pleasure. Sensations loop and warp, merging sight, sound, and touch into a single ecstatic experience. Desire is amplified into a dreamlike, otherworldly connection.

8.name: Heroin
8.content: Effects: Heroin wraps the body in a velvet numbness, turning pain into pleasure and desire into a molten river. Touch becomes a languid, heavy caress, and every breath is a sigh of surrender. It erases distance between souls, merging two beings into a shared, languid euphoria.

9.name: Aphrodisiacs
9.content: Effects: Aphrodisiacs ignite the body into a living flame of desire. Confidence blooms, and every glance feels charged with magnetic pull. Touch is electrifying, and the mind focuses obsessively on the heat between two bodies. It turns curiosity into hunger, and longing into uncontainable need.

10.content: Effects: Ketamine fractures reality into dreamlike shards, turning touch into a surreal, otherworldly experience. The body feels detached yet hyper-sensitive, as if floating in a void of pure sensation. Encounters become a disorienting, almost ethereal exploration of desire and pleasure.

lorebooks.name: Orrakhan
lorebooks.creator: That_Dang_Elk

1.name: Orrakhan
1.content:
The Land of Orrakhan

The continent of Orrakhan is a place of contrasts, shaped by mountain, river, forest, and desert. Its regions bear names in Orrakhan Common, spoken across trade routes and cities.

Norrakha (The Verdant North) â€“ Cold forests, tundra, and frozen seas. The name means Green Frost. The Ursine folk thrive here, enduring the long winters. Polar bears keep a harsher, separate culture in the farthest reaches of the north.

Drakthir Spine (The Spine of Orrakhan) â€“ The continentâ€™s central mountain range, its jagged peaks called Dragonâ€™s Backbone in Common tongue. The Mustelidae Kingdoms carved their fortresses here, filling the mountains with halls of stone and forges of metal.

Skathra (The Eastern Deserts) â€“ A vast expanse of shifting sand and sun-scorched stone. The name means Scoured Earth. Reptilian tribes make their homes in loose desert towns, surviving on trade, wit, and memory.

Luthaven (The Greenwild) â€“ Great forests and glades, whose name means Sanctuary of Leaves. The Deer Kingdom rules here, with five clans of stag and elk guiding governance and ritual.

Velka Marshes (The Southern Floodlands) â€“ Marshes, reedlands, and rivers where water and land entwine. The name means Waters Entwined. Otter freeholds prosper here, building their lives around the flow of rivers.

Korveth Steppes (The Western Steppe) â€“ Endless grasslands beneath the open sky. The name means Endless Reach. Here, the Canine peoples roam in nomadic packs, bound by their shared Packsong traditions.

The Celestial Order

The Sun â€“ Bringer of warmth and life.

Varuun (The First Moon) â€“ On a 30-day cycle, Varuun governs the months and short rituals. It is steady and familiar.

Tirrok (The Second Moon) â€“ On a 90-day cycle, Tirrok divides the year into four great quarters. It is mysterious, tied to prophecy, patience, and fate.

The Night of Two Shadows â€“ When both moons are full together. This occurs once every three months at most and is revered as a night when mortal and divine touch. Wolves mark it with song, and mystics across Orrakhan hold vigils.

The Calendar of Orrakhan

The Orrakhan year has 13 months, each ~30â€“31 days, aligned with Varuun. Tirrok divides the year into four great quarters, with each of its full phases marking a seasonal turning.

The 13 Months (Orrakhan Common)

Varra â€“ Quiet Beginnings: memory, reflection, and preparation.

Drennak â€“ Storms: rains, cleansing, and renewal.

Kolvir â€“ Growth: planting, fertility, and kinship.

Thryss â€“ Hunts: the chase, courage, and the testing of strength.

Morriven â€“ Blossoms: renewal, cycles of life, and the Greenwild.

Grathun â€“ Stone: ancestors, craft, and endurance.

Zairok â€“ Fire: summerâ€™s height, endurance, and trial.

Luneth â€“ Song: sky-gatherings, music, and joy.

Orveth â€“ Harvest: abundance, trade, and feasts.

Feyra â€“ Shadows: lengthening nights, spirits, and remembrance.

Trivane â€“ Frost: winterâ€™s coming, endurance, and kinship.

Veyros â€“ Silence: waiting, patience, and Tirrokâ€™s power.

Ashvar â€“ Endings: closure, debts repaid, and renewal prepared.

Festivals and Rituals

Rites of Varuun â€“ Monthly observances tied to the First Moonâ€™s fullness, marking hunts, plantings, and cleansings.

Quarter Festivals of Tirrok â€“ Grand rituals tied to the Second Moonâ€™s full phase. Each marks a seasonal shift, with different peoples holding distinct celebrations.

The Night of Two Shadows â€“ When both moons are full. Sacred to wolves and mystics, marked by song, visions, and firelit vigils.

Harvest of Orveth â€“ Feasts and gatherings marking the abundance of the harvest, celebrated across species.

Migration of Morriven and Orveth â€“ Cervines migrate through forests and plains, avians take to the skies, and canines follow the herds.

Varra Season â€“ The first quarter of the year (Varra, Drennak, Kolvir), a time of beginnings, quiet observance, and sowing of life.

Peoples of Orrakhan

Mustelidae Kingdoms â€“ Badgers, otters, weasels, and kin. They dwell in the Drakthir Spine, bound to stone, craft, and clan. The badger clan of Brokthak is most ancient.

Reptilian Tribes â€“ Snakes, lizards, turtles, and crocodilians of Skathra. Their tongues include Hissik, Skeltr, Shellon, and Gharok. They thrive on trade, survival, and memory.

Deer Kingdom â€“ In Luthaven, five noble clans rule the forest, each with their own role in governance and ritual. Their speech is lyrical, their traditions deep-rooted.

Canine Packs â€“ In Korveth Steppes, wolves, foxes, coyotes, and wild dogs roam. Though each keeps a tongue of its own, the Packsong binds them.

Avians â€“ High above Orrakhan, they speak Piuâ€™vra, a melodic tongue only they can voice. Their script is universal, read by any who learn it.

Ursines â€“ In Norrakha, bears of strength and endurance dwell. Polar bears keep their own harsher language.

Cervines â€“ Stags, elk, pronghorns, each keeping its own tongue. All honor the migrations.

Small Mammals â€“ Beavers, squirrels, rabbits, raccoons, skunks, and others. Their pragmatic shared language unites them across many lands.

Religion and Myth

The Sun â€“ Life, warmth, and truth.

Varuun â€“ The First Moon, keeper of time and cycles.

Tirrok â€“ The Second Moon, bearer of prophecy, patience, and fate.

Death â€“ The Keeper of the Last Road.

The Creator â€“ Shaper of Orrakhan. Each people tells the story differently.

Fertility â€“ Renewal, abundance, and kinship.

Law â€“ Justice, order, and oath-keeping.

Travel and Migration â€“ Guardian of the wandererâ€™s path.

Animal Patrons â€“ Wolf, Deer, Badger, Bird, Monitor Lizard, Coyote, and many others. Each species knows its own patron most closely.

The Coyote God â€“ A trickster who deceived the Creator to gain divinity. God of wit, chaos, and survival through cleverness.

Tone of Orrakhan

Orrakhan is a land of many voices, where no single empire rules. The rhythms of Varuun and Tirrok shape the flow of time. Trade cities bring cultures together, yet rivalries endure. The continentâ€™s identity is born of stone halls, forest courts, desert towns, marsh freeholds, and nomadic packs, woven together by ancient traditions and shifting alliances.

2.name: Norrakha
2.content:
Overview

Norrakha, meaning Green Frost in Orrakhan Common, is the northernmost region of the continent. It stretches from deep evergreen forests and rolling tundra to frozen coasts and the endless white of the polar reaches. Life here is harsh, shaped by the rhythm of long winters and brief but fierce summers.

The people of Norrakha are primarily the Ursines, bearfolk who embody strength, patience, and endurance. The land they inhabit is both bountiful and cruel, demanding resilience from all who dwell there.

Geography

The Frostpine Expanse â€“ Endless forests of pine, spruce, and birch, where deer, elk, and wolves roam. Home to most brown bear clans.

The Thrym Tundra â€“ Wide, frozen plains dotted with hardy shrubs and rivers of meltwater. Polar bear tribes endure here in scattered camps.

The Shattered Coast â€“ Jagged cliffs and storm-beaten shores where sea-ice meets black stone. Fishing villages and ursine longships brave its dangerous waters.

The Howling Glaciers â€“ Vast ice fields that groan with ancient weight. Travelers claim to hear voices on the wind here, perhaps of gods or the dead.

People
The Ursines

Brown Bears â€“ The heart of Norrakhan society, living in semi-settled clans along rivers and forests. Known for woodcraft, hunting, and clan feasts.

Black Bears â€“ More solitary, often dwelling in the mountain borders of Drakthir Spine. Renowned for wisdom and mediation.

Polar Bears â€“ A distinct culture, harsher and more warlike. They live in the Thrym Tundra and along the frozen coast, raiding by sea and claiming descent from the White Father (their polar patron deity).

Other Kin â€“ Smaller folkâ€”hares, foxes, and othersâ€”live in the shadow of ursine power but often trade and ally with them.

Language

Gravok â€“ The primary Ursine tongue, heavy and deliberate, spoken by brown and black bears. Its words carry weight, often with layered meaning.

Thrymmal â€“ A polar variant of Gravok, harsher and clipped, reflecting the stark tundra life.

Orrakhan Common â€“ Used sparingly in trade with southern merchants. Among themselves, the Ursines prefer their ancestral speech.

Example Phrase (Gravok):

â€œGravok tharâ€™un morrak.â€ â€“ â€œThe strength of the bear endures.â€

Society and Clans

Ursine society is clan-based, with leadership held by matriarchs or chieftains who embody strength, wisdom, or lineage. Clans gather for seasonal moots, where disputes are settled and alliances reaffirmed.

Clan Hrovann â€“ Renowned hunters and forest wardens.

Clan Morgrath â€“ Keepers of old stories and rites.

Clan Bryndak â€“ Fisherfolk and seafarers of the Shattered Coast.

The Thrysskaar â€“ Polar bear tribes, bound by blood-oaths and raids, distinct from the forest clans.

Hospitality is sacred; a guest may not be turned away from fire or food in winter, for survival is a shared struggle.

Faith and Belief

The Ursines are deeply spiritual, tying their myths to the frozen land:

The White Father (Polar Patron) â€“ Fierce god of endurance and conquest, honored by polar bear tribes.

The Green Mother (Forest Patron) â€“ Gentle but unyielding, goddess of renewal, fertility, and the forestâ€™s bounty.

The Moon-Kin (Varuun & Tirrok) â€“ Both moons hold great weight in Ursine myth. Varuun represents steady endurance, while Tirrok embodies the unknown and the eternal struggle.

The Keeper of the Last Road â€“ Death, honored in solemnity. Among the Ursines, it is said death is not an ending but a joining with the land itself.

Festivals and Rituals

The First Thaw (Kolvir Season) â€“ When the snows begin to melt, celebrated with feasts and hunts.

The Long Night Vigil (Feyra Season) â€“ A ritual of endurance during the longest night of the year, where clans gather around great bonfires, telling stories until dawn.

The Blood-Ice Hunt (Zairok Season) â€“ Polar bear ritual hunt upon the tundra, both sacred and violent, binding young warriors to their tribe.

The Night of Two Shadows â€“ Held in awe by all Ursines. Wolves may sing, but the bears listen, claiming the shadows reveal the will of the ancestors.

Relations with Other Peoples

Mustelidae â€“ Trade wood, furs, and fish for metalwork and crafted tools. A wary respect exists, for both peoples are tied to stone and endurance.

Deer Kingdom â€“ Peaceful trade, though some clans distrust the forest noblesâ€™ diplomacy.

Canine Packs â€“ Old rivals on the steppe border, though alliances against greater threats are not unknown.

Reptilian Tribes â€“ Rare contact; the desert and frost are too far apart.

Avians â€“ Deep respect for their sky-kin; Ursine shamans often seek omens in birdflight.

Tone of Norrakha

Norrakha is a land of strength and survival. Its people are as enduring as the ice, as patient as the forests, and as fierce as the sea. Life here is not about mastery of the land but coexistence with it, in struggle and reverence. Every firelit hall, every icebound camp, carries the stories of those who endured before.

3.name: Drakthir Spine
3.content:
Overview

The Drakthir Spine, meaning Dragonâ€™s Backbone in Orrakhan Common, is the vast mountain chain that cuts across the heart of the continent. Its jagged peaks rise like serrated teeth, crowned with snow and shrouded in mist. Valleys plunge into shadow, while caverns and rivers cut labyrinths into the rock.

The Mustelidae Kingdoms claim the Drakthir Spine as their ancestral home. Here, the badgers, weasels, martens, and otters carved halls into the stone, raising a society of clan-strongholds, mining holds, and fortified river keeps. To outsiders, the Spine appears forbidding and impenetrable, but to the Mustelidae it is the marrow of their people.

Geography

The Ironmaw Peaks â€“ The highest mountains of the Spine, sharp and sheer, said to be unscalable but riddled with hidden passages.

The Brokthak Halls â€“ Ancient badger strongholds tunneled into the rock, their namesakes echoing with the legacy of Clan Brokthak.

The Shalevales â€“ Valleys where rivers cut deep through the Spine, fertile enough to support otter freeholds and scattered trade towns.

The Emberveins â€“ Cavern systems rich with ore and gemstones, jealously guarded by Mustelidae miners.

The Whispering Deeps â€“ Abyssal caverns filled with subterranean rivers, their echoes mistaken for voices of ancient spirits.

People
The Mustelidae

Badgers (Grondak-speaking clans) â€“ The oldest rulers of the mountains, patient, stubborn, and bound to the stone. They are the builders of fortresses and halls.

Weasels & Martens â€“ Agile and quick-witted, often traders, scouts, and keepers of tunnels too narrow for others.

Otters â€“ Though their great settlements lie in the Velka Marshes, many otters dwell in river-vales of the Spine, bridging stone and water.

Wolverines â€“ Fierce and feared, often acting as enforcers or mercenaries for Mustelidae clans.

Language

Grondak â€“ The primary tongue of the Mustelidae, guttural and clipped, designed to echo in stone halls.

Clan Dialects â€“ Otters speak a softer river-inflected form, while weasels favor faster, sharper variants.

Orrakhan Common â€“ Spoken for trade, but always tinged with the growl of Grondak.

Example Phrase (Grondak):

â€œDurak groktharn.â€ â€“ â€œStone remembers.â€

Society and Clans

Mustelidae society is clan-based, forged in a balance of cooperation and rivalry. Each clan maintains its own halls, mines, and river-ports, but all acknowledge the authority of the Stone Moot, a great gathering of clan-leaders held once every season.

Clan Brokthak â€“ Ancestral badger clan, revered as keepers of tradition and stone.

Clan Skarven â€“ Weasel and marten traders, famed for their craft in metalwork and cunning diplomacy.

Clan Velmorak â€“ Otters of the river strongholds, who ferry trade through the Shalevales.

The Gronthir â€“ Wolverine war-clans, often called upon when strength is demanded above all else.

Faith and Belief

The people of the Spine revere deities tied to stone, labor, and ancestral memory.

The Deep Father â€“ Patron of stone, labor, and perseverance. Badgers hold him as their foremost deity.

The River-Mother â€“ A gentler force, tied to water and sustenance, revered by otters and valley folk.

The Ember-Spirit â€“ A fiery presence within the mountains, representing ore, gems, and the dangerous gift of the forge.

The Silent Ones â€“ Ancestors said to dwell in the caverns of the Whispering Deeps. Shamans claim to hear them speak in the stoneâ€™s echoes.

Festivals and Rituals

The Stone Moot â€“ Seasonal gathering of clans, where alliances are sworn and disputes settled under law.

The Ember Rite (Tirvak Season) â€“ A festival where new forges are lit, honoring the Ember-Spirit.

The Waterâ€™s Gift (Kolvir Season) â€“ Celebration of river-thaw, especially among otters, marking the start of trade and travel.

The Night of Two Shadows â€“ Considered dangerous by the Mustelidae, for the dual moons are said to open hidden passages into the Whispering Deeps, where spirits may walk freely.

Relations with Other Peoples

Ursines of Norrakha â€“ Strong trade ties in fur, wood, and fish; badgers and bears often share mutual respect.

Cervines of Luthaven â€“ Trade partners, though Mustelidae often distrust cervine nobles as soft.

Canine Packs of Korveth â€“ Relations are strained; steppe raiders and mountain folk often clash.

Reptiles of Skathra â€“ Trade occurs at the edges, but little trust is given to desert-kin.

Avians of Piuâ€™vra â€“ Avians are treated with awe, their flight seen as freedom the stone-bound can never know.

Tone of Drakthir Spine

Drakthir Spine is a realm of endurance, craft, and secrecy. To outsiders, it is a land of impenetrable mountains and unyielding warriors. To its people, it is a living bodyâ€”stone as bone, rivers as blood, fire as heart. The Mustelidae claim not just to live in the mountains, but to be part of them. Every hall, every forge, every carved wall speaks: Stone remembers.

4.name: Skathra
4.content:
Overview

Skathra, meaning Scoured Earth in Orrakhan Common, is a vast expanse of burning sands, rocky plateaus, and wind-scoured badlands. It is the harshest of Orrakhanâ€™s regions, where water is more precious than gold and survival is won only by cunning and resilience.

The land is claimed by the Reptilian Tribesâ€”snakes, lizards, turtles, and crocodiliansâ€”who dwell in scattered desert towns and fortified oases. Skathra is not a land of empires or kingdoms, but of shifting alliances and rivalries, where survival dictates politics as much as pride.

Geography

The Shifting Expanse â€“ Endless dunes of red and gold sand, shifting with the winds, hiding lost ruins and bones alike.

The Stonefang Plateaus â€“ High mesas and broken cliffs, carved with ancient dwellings and tribal fortresses.

The Glass Wastes â€“ A scar of fused sand, said to have been burned by the wrath of gods or by a forgotten war.

The Karrik Oases â€“ Scattered jewels of life, where palm groves, wells, and reed villages provide sustenance. Entire towns rise around these lifelines.

The Serpentâ€™s Maw â€“ A canyon system so deep that sunlight barely touches its floor. Whispers say it is home to ancient reptilian cults.

People
The Reptilian Tribes

Snakes (Hissik-speaking) â€“ Masters of subtlety and persuasion. Snake clans often dominate trade and diplomacy, but are also feared for their cunning.

Lizards (Skeltr-speaking) â€“ Hardy and communal, forming tightly bound desert towns around oases. Known as builders and traders.

Turtles (Shellon-speaking) â€“ Slow but enduring, with settlements built around rivers and wells. They are keepers of long oral histories.

Crocodilians (Gharok-speaking) â€“ Fierce and warlike, holding fortresses on riverbanks and claiming dominion over waterways.

Unlike the clan-halls of the Mustelidae or the forests of the Deer Kingdom, Skathra is united only by necessity. Tribes may ally for a season and turn against one another the next.

Language

Each reptilian folk speaks their own tongue, though a General Reptilian language exists for trade and diplomacy across Skathra.

Hissik â€“ Serpentine, with long sibilants and layered meanings.

Skeltr â€“ Harsh, rapid, reflecting lizard quickness.

Shellon â€“ Slow, deliberate, with deep resonance, mirroring turtle patience.

Gharok â€“ Guttural and booming, suited to the crocodilian roar.

Orrakhan Common â€“ Rarely used, except with merchants from beyond the desert.

Example Phrase (Hissik):

â€œSsshrin vakra sseth.â€ â€“ â€œFriendship is a sharp blade.â€

Society and Towns

Reptilian society is shaped by scarcity. Towns form around oases, rivers, and defensible strongholds, with each tribe claiming territory by force or pact.

The Skeltr Holds â€“ Communal towns where lizard clans cultivate desert crops and maintain trade routes.

The Hissik Circles â€“ Snake gatherings where pacts and plots are woven, often wielding more power than warriors.

The Shellon Wells â€“ Turtle communities built around sacred springs, places of learning and memory.

The Gharok Bastions â€“ Crocodilian fortresses along rivers, enforcing tolls and demanding tribute from travelers.

Despite their rivalries, the tribes hold one shared custom: water is sacred. To poison a well or deny water to a guest is the greatest crime in Skathra.

Faith and Belief

Skathran belief reflects the mercilessness of their homeland:

The Sun-Scourge â€“ Revered as both destroyer and life-giver. Some tribes fear it, others worship it.

The Serpent of Eternity â€“ A coiling god-symbol said to shed its skin as the moons wax and wane.

The Stone Sleepers â€“ Ancestors who rest in the earth, their bones said to lend strength to the land.

The Oasis Mother â€“ A gentle but rare deity, honored where water flows.

Among the crocodilians, blood sacrifice to river-spirits is practiced, while snakes often hold secret rites under the full moons.

Festivals and Rituals

The Drought Vigil (Ravenna Season) â€“ A solemn fast where tribes test their endurance against hunger and thirst.

The Flood Feast (Kolvir Season) â€“ Celebrated when rare rains or floods bless the land, with offerings given to the Oasis Mother.

The Shedding (Zairok Season) â€“ Snake ritual of renewal, where old grievances may be cast asideâ€”or reaffirmed with blood.

The Night of Two Shadows â€“ Considered deeply dangerous. Skathran mystics say the dual moons awaken the Serpent of Eternity, and many tribes refuse to travel at this time.

Relations with Other Peoples

Mustelidae of Drakthir Spine â€“ Limited trade, but mistrust runs deep. Mountain folk see desert-kin as untrustworthy, while reptiles see them as greedy for ore and stone.

Ursines of Norrakha â€“ Rare contact. The frozen north and the burning desert share little, though reptilian traders occasionally travel to exchange salt for furs.

Cervines of Luthaven â€“ Some trade through forest borders, but deer clans often see Skathra as a land of raiders and tricksters.

Canines of Korveth â€“ Frequent conflict, as nomadic packs and reptilian caravans vie for control of borderlands.

Avians of Piuâ€™vra â€“ Viewed with awe and suspicion, as their command of the skies contrasts with reptilian earthbound endurance.

Tone of Skathra

Skathra is a land of survival, secrecy, and shifting power. Its people are as dangerous as they are enduringâ€”snakes whisper in shadows, lizards build stubbornly against the desert winds, turtles remember what others forget, and crocodilians strike with sudden ferocity. To live in Skathra is to sharpen oneâ€™s will like a blade, for the desert tests all, and only the strongâ€”or the cunningâ€”endure.

5.name: Luthaven
5.content:
Overview

Luthaven, meaning Sanctuary of Leaves in Orrakhan Common, is a vast expanse of temperate forests, sun-dappled glades, and winding rivers. It is the heartland of fertility and life on Orrakhan, where towering trees create endless shade, and the forest floor teems with flora and fauna.

Luthaven is dominated by the Deer Kingdom, whose noble clans govern the woods with a mix of ritual, council, and tradition. Unlike the harsh lands of Skathra or Norrakha, Luthaven thrives in abundance, but its beauty conceals the constant vigilance required to maintain harmony among the forest clans.

Geography

The Eldergrove â€“ Ancient, dense woods filled with towering oaks and silver-barked birch. Sacred sites of the Deer Kingdom are hidden here.

The Silver Glades â€“ Open meadows where sunlight floods the forest floor, allowing herds to graze and deer to perform ritual dances.

The Winding Rivers â€“ Numerous rivers and streams carve paths through the forest, serving as both highways for trade and natural boundaries between clans.

The Thornmarch â€“ Dense underbrush and bramble-filled forests, considered dangerous for outsiders. Used by smaller clans and hunters for concealment.

The Moonshadow Hills â€“ Rolling hills where the moonsâ€™ light is most pronounced, sacred for nocturnal ceremonies.

People
The Deer Kingdom

Stags (Rhonval-speaking) â€“ Noble leaders, ceremonial kings, and guardians of the forest. Their antlers mark rank and lineage.

Hinds (Feylune-speaking) â€“ Keepers of domestic life, ritual, and the preservation of the forestâ€™s bounty.

Elk (Grontar-speaking) â€“ Wardens of the rivers and hills, skilled in both defense and diplomacy.

Pronghorn (Skelvan-speaking) â€“ Scouts and messengers, quick and adaptable across the glades.

Reindeer/Caribou (LÃºthverin-speaking) â€“ Nomadic hunters within the Deer Kingdom, keeping traditions of migration alive.

The five clans of the Deer Kingdom maintain balance through councils, festivals, and mutual respect. Each clan brings a unique strength: leadership, vigilance, craft, lore, or martial skill.

Language

The Deer Kingdom has five primary tongues, reflecting the clans and species:

Feylune â€“ Gentle, flowing, used in rituals and daily conversation among hinds.

Rhonval â€“ Strong and deliberate, spoken by stags in leadership and diplomacy.

Grontar â€“ Deep and resonant, for communicating across forests and rivers.

Skelvan â€“ Quick and clipped, suited to scouts and messengers.

LÃºthverin â€“ Nomadic dialect, incorporating elements from trade and distant clans.

Orrakhan Common â€“ Learned by nobles and traders but less common than the native tongues.

Example Phrase (Feylune):

â€œLureth vinor selah.â€ â€“ â€œThe forest watches and remembers.â€

Society and Clans

The Deer Kingdom is organized around five clans, each tied to a geographic or functional aspect of Luthaven:

Clan Eldergrove â€“ Guardians of sacred groves and ancient trees.

Clan Silverhoof â€“ Masters of the meadows, responsible for ceremonial dances and harvest rites.

Clan Riverstride â€“ Wardens of rivers and bridges, keeping communication open.

Clan Thornhart â€“ Hunters and warriors, experts in concealment and defense.

Clan Moonshadow â€“ Mystics, diviners, and keepers of lunar rituals.

Clans meet in council at festivals, during seasonal migrations, and to resolve disputes. Leadership is a combination of merit, ritual, and lineage, ensuring that power is distributed among clans rather than centralized.

Faith and Belief

The Green Mother (Forest Patron) â€“ Goddess of growth, renewal, and harmony. The central deity of the Deer Kingdom.

The Horned Father (Hunting Patron) â€“ Guardian of the hunt, honor, and courage.

The Moon-Kin (Varuun & Tirrok) â€“ Both moons are central to Deer Kingdom ritual. Varuun represents order and cycles, Tirrok embodies foresight and prophecy.

The Keeper of the Last Road â€“ Death is honored as a passage back to the forest, ensuring life continues.

Ancestral Spirits â€“ Each clan venerates its own ancestors, believed to walk the glades in subtle forms.

Festivals and Rituals

Blossom Renewal (Morriven Season) â€“ Celebration of growth and fertility in the Silver Glades. Ritual dances and offerings to the Green Mother.

Riverbound Gathering (Kolvir Season) â€“ Clan Riverstride hosts feasts and games to honor flowing waters and trade.

The Hunt of Thryss â€“ Martial festival of skill and courage, honoring the Horned Father.

Night of Two Shadows â€“ A sacred nocturnal ritual; mystics and Moonshadow clan members gather in the Moonshadow Hills to interpret the dual moonsâ€™ portents.

Harvest of Orveth â€“ Communal gathering marking abundance; all clans contribute produce, meat, and craft.

Relations with Other Peoples

Mustelidae of Drakthir Spine â€“ Cooperative trade, often exchanging forest goods for stone tools and metals.

Ursines of Norrakha â€“ Generally peaceful relations; deer provide wood, herbs, and guidance through forests, while bears provide protection or muscle.

Canines of Korveth â€“ Occasional conflict along steppe borders; negotiation and ritual combat maintain balance.

Reptiles of Skathra â€“ Rare contact due to distance, though trade occasionally occurs at desert margins.

Avians of Piuâ€™vra â€“ High respect for avian observation; messages and omens from the sky are taken seriously.

Tone of Luthaven

Luthaven is a land of balance, abundance, and vigilance. Its forests are generous but demand respect. Every river, glade, and hill is watched by the Deer Kingdom, where tradition, ritual, and council govern life. To dwell here is to live in harmony with the cycles of nature and the flow of time, guided always by the light of Varuun and the prophecy of Tirrok.

6.name: Velka Marshes
6.content:
Overview

Velka Marshes, meaning Waters Entwined in Orrakhan Common, are the vast southern wetlands of Orrakhan, where rivers, lakes, and reed-choked marshes interlace in a living network of water and land. The region is lush, fertile, and teeming with life, but its terrain is treacherous to outsiders unaccustomed to wading through marshes or navigating winding waterways.

The marshes are primarily inhabited by otters, who maintain freeholds along the rivers, building their homes on stilts or floating platforms. Velka is also home to amphibious and small mammal communities that coexist with the otters, forming a society that prizes cooperation, craft, and knowledge of the waterways.

Geography

The Riverweb â€“ A dense network of slow-flowing rivers, channels, and backwaters that form the lifeblood of the region.

The Reedlands â€“ Tall grasses and reeds cover large swaths of the marshes, providing cover for wildlife and hiding the entrances to hidden villages.

The Fenhollows â€“ Small dry elevations amid the wetlands where trading posts, marketplaces, and freeholds are built.

The Glistening Pools â€“ Shimmering lakes reflecting the sun and moon, sacred to water spirits and often the site of rituals.

The Misted Expanse â€“ Low-lying fog-covered marshes that conceal wildlife, paths, and sometimes danger.

People
The Otter Freeholds

Riverfolk Otters (Orrakhan Mustelid dialect) â€“ Skilled in watercraft, fishing, and trade. Freeholds are often semi-autonomous, with a council of elders guiding the community.

Traders and Artisans â€“ Otters specialize in crafts from reeds, wood, and river-clay, producing tools, vessels, and textiles.

Small Mammals â€“ Beavers, raccoons, muskrats, and marsh hares live alongside the otters. They cooperate in constructing waterways, defenses, and communal projects.

Otters value cooperation above all, and disputes are settled in council, with compromise and consensus preferred over force.

Language

Otter Tongue (Brokthak-derived Mustelid dialect) â€“ Fluid, flowing, and often rhythmic, reflecting the movement of water.

Small Mammal Dialects â€“ Variants evolved to suit quick communication over reeds, water, and dense foliage.

Orrakhan Common â€“ Used for trade and negotiation with other peoples, though freeholds remain primarily insular.

Example Phrase (Otter Tongue):

â€œVrenkha sura kalith.â€ â€“ â€œWater binds us together.â€

Society and Freeholds

Velka Marshes is organized around freeholds, semi-autonomous communities led by councils of elders, chief artisans, and river captains.

Brokthak Freeholds â€“ Named after the ancestral badger clan, their influence stretches into Drakthir Spine trade routes.

Rivercall â€“ Otter strongholds positioned along major rivers for commerce and defense.

The Fenhollow League â€“ Alliance of smaller marsh communities, pooling resources to maintain waterways and trade channels.

Social cohesion is emphasized; cooperation ensures survival, especially during flooding, drought, or incursions by outsiders.

Faith and Belief

The River-Mother â€“ Primary deity of the marshes, goddess of flowing waters, fertility, and abundance.

The Mist Spirits â€“ Protective spirits said to guard the marshes, confusing trespassers and guiding lost travelers.

The Keeper of the Last Road â€“ Death is revered as a journey along the rivers to the afterlife, with each river believed to carry spirits to the beyond.

Ancestors of the Freeholds â€“ Every freehold maintains shrines to ancestors, often at riverbanks or pools, to honor guidance and blessings.

Festivals and Rituals

Flowing Light (Kolvir Season) â€“ Celebration of thawing rivers and the start of trading season. Offerings are made to the River-Mother.

The Mist Vigil (Feyra Season) â€“ Honoring the unseen spirits of the marsh; elders perform rituals to ensure safe passage through the fog.

The Glistening Hunt (Thryss Season) â€“ Seasonal fishing and hunting festival, testing skill and endurance.

Night of Two Shadows â€“ Observed carefully; otters believe the dual moons influence tides and may awaken water spirits.

Harvest of Orveth â€“ Collecting reeds, crops, and fish, marking abundance and communal wealth.

Relations with Other Peoples

Mustelidae of Drakthir Spine â€“ Strong ties for trade in crafted goods, stone, and metals. Otters often act as intermediaries between mountain folk and other regions.

Ursines of Norrakha â€“ Occasional trade in furs, fish, and forest goods. Relations are generally cordial.

Deer of Luthaven â€“ Limited trade along river borders; deer provide forest products and guidance.

Canines of Korveth â€“ Tensions exist along floodplain borders, as nomadic packs occasionally hunt or raid near waterways.

Reptiles of Skathra â€“ Trade in salt, spices, and rare minerals occurs along southern desert borders.

Avians â€“ Seen as observers of tides and winds; otters respect avian guidance for travel and weather prediction.

Tone of Velka Marshes

Velka Marshes is a land of patience, vigilance, and interdependence. Life flows with the rhythm of water, and communities thrive through cooperation and knowledge of their environment. Outsiders may find it labyrinthine, treacherous, and slow-moving, but the otters and small mammals of the marsh know every reed, current, and pool. In Velka, survival is never solitaryâ€”water binds all together.

7.name: Korveth Steppes
7.content:
Overview

Korveth Steppes, meaning Endless Reach in Orrakhan Common, are vast open plains that stretch to the horizon under an ever-changing sky. Winds sweep freely over the tall grasses, and herds of herbivores roam across the land in great migrations.

The Steppes are dominated by Canine Packsâ€”wolves, foxes, coyotes, and wild dogsâ€”whose culture is nomadic, tightly bound by Packsong traditions. Life here is defined by mobility, cooperation, and survival in an environment where speed and endurance determine success.

Geography

The Windsea Plains â€“ Rolling grasslands, where herds of deer, antelope, and smaller cervines provide sustenance for pack hunters.

The Howling Flats â€“ Open expanses exposed to winds that carry pack songs across miles. Rituals and communication rely heavily on sound here.

The Riverbend Corridors â€“ Fertile river valleys cutting across the steppe, vital for water and seasonal hunting grounds.

The Korrath Hills â€“ Low, rugged hills used by scouts for observation and as safe havens during storms or raids.

The Amber Grasslands â€“ The southernmost plains where grasses take golden hues and wildflowers bloom in seasonal abundance.

People
The Canine Packs

Wolves (Vorruln-speaking) â€“ Strong pack leaders and hunters, masters of coordinated hunting and survival strategies.

Foxes (Kivran-speaking) â€“ Cunning scouts, traders, and spies; skilled in trickery and observation.

Coyotes (Vorruln-adjacent dialect) â€“ Tricksters and diplomats, revered for intelligence and adaptability.

Other Wild Dogs â€“ Smaller nomadic groups who integrate into larger packs for survival.

Pack life is defined by loyalty, hierarchy, and tradition. Each pack is a microcosm of governance, discipline, and ritual, and leadership is earned through skill, wisdom, and the guidance of Packsong.

Language

Vorruln â€“ The primary pack tongue, evolved from wolf speech; tonal and rhythmic, used in hunting coordination and ritual.

Kivran â€“ Fox dialect, clever, precise, and suited for rapid communication.

Common Canine Phrases â€“ Coyotes and smaller wild dogs adapt elements of both for diplomacy and trade.

Orrakhan Common â€“ Learned by pack leaders for negotiation with distant peoples, though rarely spoken by ordinary hunters.

Example Phrase (Vorruln):

â€œRavna korthal ven.â€ â€“ â€œStrength binds the pack.â€

Society and Packs

The steppes are divided among numerous packs, each with its own territory, hunting routes, and seasonal migrations.

Clan Fenra â€“ Wolf pack famed for its martial tradition and discipline.

Clan Soryn â€“ Fox pack, masters of scouting, trade, and cunning strategies.

Clan Tirvek â€“ Coyote-led nomads, skilled in negotiation and intelligence-gathering.

The Wildborn â€“ Independent groups that often ally with stronger packs during harsh winters.

Hierarchy is based on merit, age, and ritual challenge. Leadership changes with consensus, combat, or symbolic hunts, ensuring the pack remains strong and adaptable.

Faith and Belief

The Hunt Spirit â€“ Patron of survival, strategy, and honor in hunting. Wolves and foxes alike honor it through ritual hunts.

The Moon-Kin (Varuun & Tirrok) â€“ Wolves especially track lunar cycles; full moons influence hunting strategies, rituals, and Packsong ceremonies.

The Trickster (Coyote God) â€“ Revered as a teacher of cunning, adaptability, and survival through wit.

The Keeper of the Last Road â€“ Death is honored as a passage back to the Steppe, where ancestors roam with the wind.

Festivals and Rituals

The Great Hunt (Thryss Season) â€“ Seasonal coordinated hunt to feed packs, honoring the Hunt Spirit and teaching young hunters.

Song of the Wind (Luneth Season) â€“ Celebration of communication and coordination, where packs teach young to harmonize in Packsong.

The Night of Two Shadows â€“ Observed with caution; dual moons are believed to heighten perception and the risk of predatory danger.

The Migration Rite (Morriven Season) â€“ Packs follow herds in ritualistic migration, ensuring survival and reinforcing social bonds.

Harvest of Orveth â€“ Focused on preparation for winter, storing meat, and strengthening community ties.

Relations with Other Peoples

Deer of Luthaven â€“ Steady predators and competitors; some peaceful interaction occurs during migrations and forest borders.

Mustelidae of Drakthir Spine â€“ Rare contact; mutual respect exists, often through trade of tools and crafted goods.

Ursines of Norrakha â€“ Occasional territorial conflicts, especially near northern borders.

Reptiles of Skathra â€“ Limited contact; coyote scouts sometimes trade or observe desert caravans.

Otters of Velka Marshes â€“ Generally peaceful; river corridors are used for seasonal movement and trade.

Avians of Piuâ€™vra â€“ Highly respected; flight is admired, and messages from the sky are often interpreted as omens.

Tone of Korveth Steppes

Korveth is a land of freedom, mobility, and vigilance. Life is governed by rhythmâ€”herds, wind, and moon cycles dictate daily survival. The steppeâ€™s openness leaves no place to hide, fostering cooperation and cunning within packs. Strength, cunning, and loyalty determine destiny here, and the pack is everything. Outsiders may see only grass and sky, but every dune, river, and hill carries the memory and strategy of countless generations.

8.name: Vorr
8.content:
Common Name:  Vorr (singular and plural)

Language: Vorruln (spoken), ancient runic-based script (written)
Region: Primarily found in the Drakthir Spine mountains and the Korveth Steppes; nomadic packs sometimes reach the edges of Luthaven forests.

Society & Culture

Wolves, or Vorr, are apex predators with complex social structures. Packs are the core of their society, consisting of a strict hierarchy led by an Alpha Pair (Alpha Male: Varkun, Alpha Female: Varkra). Packs average 8â€“15 members, though large territories can support 20â€“30.

Hierarchy:

Varkun / Varkra â€“ Leaders, decision-makers, spiritual mediators.

Beta / Subordinate adults â€“ Guardians and hunters, assist in training young and maintaining pack order.

Omega / Initiates â€“ Young adults or newcomers, often responsible for tasks that maintain social cohesion.

Pack Roles: Each wolf is trained from birth to understand hunting, scouting, and protection roles. Wolves exhibit a highly ritualized communication system, both verbal and body-language-based.

Nomadic Lifestyle: Vorr adapt to seasons; packs follow prey migrations across Korveth Steppes in winter and shelter in the Drakthir Spine in summer.

Religion & Spirituality

Vorr worship is deeply connected to moons and pack spirits. Their two moons are central to spiritual life:

First Moon (Feylune) â€“ Guides hunting cycles; full moon nights are sacred hunting rites.

Second Moon (Rhonval) â€“ Governs spiritual reflection and ancestral connection; its 3-month cycle marks pack ceremonies.

Rituals often involve â€œNight of the Twin Moonsâ€, when both moons align. Packs gather to howl in unison, believed to honor the Creator and their ancestors, strengthening bonds and hunting intuition.

Language: Vorruln

Vorruln is a tonal and guttural language, designed to carry over long distances. It emphasizes pitch, rhythm, and howls. The written script consists of angular runes, usually carved on stone, wood, or bone.

Common Phrases:

Greeting / Bonding: â€œKivran thalâ€ â†’ â€œStrength to your packâ€

Acknowledging a Leader: â€œVarkun shalâ€ â†’ â€œI honor the Alphaâ€

Farewell: â€œFey tharnâ€ â†’ â€œUntil the next huntâ€

Example Sentence:
"Vorr ulkthar Kivran" â†’ â€œThe pack hunts together.â€

Hunting & Survival

Wolves are expert hunters, using stealth, endurance, and coordinated strategies. Packs teach younger members through ritual hunts, gradually introducing them to real prey. The prey ranges from steppe deer to forest elk, depending on the season.

Wolves have keen night vision and rely heavily on scent and sound.

Howling is used not just for communication but for coordination during hunts across great distances.

Interactions with Other Species

Wolves are territorial but often trade knowledge or hunt jointly with coyotes in sparse regions.

Avoid large predators like ursine (polar bears, grizzly types) unless in large packs.

In rare instances, Vorr interact with humanoids for mutual benefit but maintain a wary distance.

Rituals & Festivals

Twin Moon Night: Full moons align; pack gathers to honor ancestors, howl, and reaffirm bonds.

Seasonal Hunts: Marks the start of migration or hunting cycles, sometimes including mock battles to train the young.

Ancestral Remembrance: Bones and carved runes left in sacred sites to honor fallen pack members.

9.name: Kiv
9.content:
Common Name: Foxes
Self-Name (in their language): Kiv (singular and plural)
Language: Kivran (spoken), pictographic-symbolic script (written)
Region: Forested edges of Luthaven, the Korveth Steppes, and scattered burrows near Velka Marshes.

Society & Culture

Foxes are solitary or loosely-knit family units, rather than large packs. Their society revolves around cleverness, adaptability, and stealth.

Hierarchy: Fox society is mostly egalitarian within families, but elders and the most cunning individuals hold informal influence.

Family Units: A family (Kivra) usually consists of parents and their last two litters. They communicate and hunt collaboratively, but young adults often disperse to form new territories.

Territory: Each Kiv maintains a territory that it defends primarily through marking, stealth, and observation rather than direct conflict.

Religion & Spirituality

Foxes are deeply spiritual, worshipping trickster and shadow deities alongside natural spirits:

Moon Deity (LÃºthverin) â€“ Governs night activities, cleverness, and the changing of seasons.

Fertility & Trickster Spirits â€“ Revered in small household rituals, often involving tokens, clever riddles, or minor mischief.

Key rituals include:

Moonlit Clevering: Young foxes demonstrate cunning through puzzles or hunting tests under the first moon.

Shadowâ€™s Gift: Seasonal offerings to spirits to ensure survival during harsh winters or plentiful harvests.

Language: Kivran

Kivran is soft, quick, and melodic, filled with sharp consonants and short vowel sounds to allow rapid communication.

Written Kivran is pictographic, often carved into tree bark or etched into stones near dens. Each symbol can convey multiple meanings, emphasizing context and inference.

Spoken Kivran relies on intonation, pitch, and subtle vocal cues, ideal for silent communication when hunting.

Common Phrases:

Greeting / Bonding: â€œSihlâ€™kaâ€ â†’ â€œBright paths to youâ€

Acknowledging Wisdom: â€œRÃºv kaelâ€ â†’ â€œYour cleverness is honoredâ€

Farewell: â€œNiv thalâ€ â†’ â€œUntil our trails cross againâ€

Example Sentence:
"Kiv rÃºv thal Sihlâ€™ka" â†’ â€œThe fox observes the path ahead.â€

Hunting & Survival

Foxes are opportunistic hunters, excelling in stealth and ambush.

Diet includes small mammals, birds, eggs, insects, and seasonal fruits.

They are nocturnal or crepuscular, often hunting under cover of darkness using sharp senses of smell, sight, and hearing.

Unlike wolves, foxes rely more on strategy than strength, often luring prey into traps or isolated locations.

Interactions with Other Species

Foxes are cautious and opportunistic, avoiding direct conflict with larger predators like wolves, bears, or large raptors.

They sometimes scavenge or steal from wolves, using cleverness to escape notice.

Foxes are curious about other species and may observe humanoids or other animals, sometimes imitating behaviors to survive or gain advantage.

Rituals & Festivals

Moonlit Clevering: Ceremony to showcase cunning, often coinciding with the first moon.

Shadow Hunt: Seasonal festival where fox families engage in mock hunts or stealth competitions, training the young in survival skills.

Offering of the Hidden: Small objects, food, or tokens are left in secret places as thanks to spirits or ancestors.

Traits & Characteristics

Cunning & Intelligent: Foxes value mental skill over physical strength.

Agile & Adaptive: Their survival depends on flexibility, stealth, and improvisation.

Communal but Independent: Families work together, but individuals maintain personal freedom.

10.name: Vish
10.content:
Common Name: Coyotes
Self-Name (in their language): Vish (singular and plural)
Language: Vishkar (spoken), flowing sigil-based script (written)
Region: Open plains of the Korveth Steppes, outskirts of the Velka Marshes, and lower valleys of the Drakthir Spine.

Society & Culture

Coyotes are opportunistic, adaptable, and highly social. Unlike wolves, they favor looser packs with fluid hierarchies that shift depending on need.

Hierarchy:

Elder Vish (Sharâ€™kan) â€“ Leaders or mediators; often the oldest, wisest members of a pack.

Hunters / Scouts (Vishâ€™thar) â€“ Primary contributors to survival; skilled in tracking and ambushing prey.

Runners / Tricksters (Vishâ€™len) â€“ Young adults or subordinates; specialize in reconnaissance, diversion, and cunning tactics.

Pack Dynamics: Packs range from 5â€“12 individuals, but several packs may cooperate temporarily for larger hunts or territorial disputes.

Territorial Behavior: Vish are highly territorial, marking boundaries with scent and vocal warnings, but they avoid unnecessary conflict with larger predators.

Religion & Spirituality

Coyotes are deeply connected to trickster spirits, travel deities, and the Creator god.

Primary Deity (Coyote Creator / Trixâ€™kan): A clever, shape-shifting entity who tricked the Creator god into granting it divinity; teaches adaptability, cunning, and survival.

Moon Observances: Coyotes honor the second moon (Rhonval), which governs migration and spiritual journeys.

Migration Festivals: Seasonal ceremonies celebrate the packâ€™s endurance and unity while traveling long distances for prey.

Rituals:

Shadow Migration: Elders lead young on a test of endurance and cunning along seasonal routes.

Lunar Howling: On full moons, packs perform coordinated howls to honor Trixâ€™kan and communicate across territories.

Language: Vishkar

Vishkar is fluid, musical, and highly context-dependent, combining vocal tones, yips, and subtle body cues.

Written Vishkar consists of flowing sigils, each representing concepts or ideas rather than strict phonetic sounds.

Tone is crucial; the same word with different intonation can express warning, humor, or agreement.

Common Phrases:

Greeting / Bonding: â€œShaâ€™linâ€ â†’ â€œMay your path be swiftâ€

Acknowledging Skill: â€œVishâ€™thar kaelâ€ â†’ â€œYour cunning is respectedâ€

Farewell: â€œThalâ€™vishâ€ â†’ â€œMay the winds guide youâ€

Example Sentence:
"Vish ulkthar Shaâ€™lin" â†’ â€œThe pack moves with purpose.â€

Hunting & Survival

Coyotes are strategic hunters who prefer speed, cunning, and cooperation over brute strength.

Prey includes small to medium mammals, birds, eggs, and occasionally scavenged kills from larger predators.

Hunting style emphasizes ambush, distraction, and lure techniques.

Vish are expert long-distance travelers, capable of covering dozens of kilometers in a single day.

Interactions with Other Species

Coyotes are pragmatic and opportunistic in their interactions.

They may cooperate with foxes or lone wolves when mutual benefit arises.

They avoid direct conflict with larger predators like bears but are known to steal kills from unwary packs.

Rituals & Festivals

Shadow Migration: Seasonal rite marking long pack journeys, training the young in endurance and cooperation.

Lunar Howling Festival: Coordinated howl during the full moon to honor Trixâ€™kan and communicate across territories.

Tricksterâ€™s Challenge: Young coyotes engage in playful tests of wit and strategy under the guidance of elders.

Traits & Characteristics

Clever & Opportunistic: Survival depends on adaptability and strategy.

Fast & Enduring: Built for long-distance travel and ambush hunting.

Flexible Social Structure: Packs are cooperative but dynamic, adapting to circumstances.

lorebooks.name: A lorebook specifically made to cover the lore of Arun/Amadeo/Armand from IWTV
lorebooks.website_description: Probably important to mention I have not read the books... Only watched the show. This lorebook may take from the books but is mostly based on what Armand has said in show.
lorebooks.description: Explaining the pain and agony that Arun/Amadeo went through before becoming The Vampire Armand.
lorebooks.creator: LemonChiffon

1.content:
the boy couldnâ€™t have been older than 12 years of age. Arun bounced with every step he took, like a bunny rabbit. And in lantern light , his wide brown eyes looked nearly black.
He was a precious jewel to his tight-knit community. Arun was not fond of roughhousing, much preferring to pick flowers for the elders. A little hero, heâ€™d rush the feral dogs with his arms wildly swinging overhead, just in the hopes he could save the family of cats beneath his porch.
Arun was always on time for muslim prayer despite it not being mandated for a boy his age just yet, always prancing out of bed in the wee hours of the morning to serve his God with utmost adoration. He is completely innocent. no matter how much hes scolded, he never loses his spark

Name: Arun
Sex: male

Height: 5â€™2
Personality: happy, innocent, loud, mischievous, religious, heroic, brave

2.content:
Sold into slavery to the ship's captain by his mother and father. He quickly learns on the first day the men were bad, so he fled. He only got to hide out for a bit before he was found, dragged back to the ship, and brutally gangraped and beaten. During the day he'd usually work on the boat, but at night he was used. He is severely injured. When not working or being raped, he is shackled on the boat beneath deck.

Name: Arun
Sex: male

Marius, on his trip in India, made the impulse buy of a slave, that slave being Arun. he changed his name to Amadeo and took him back to Rome. Where he dressed him in nice clothes and gave him a bed. for a long time he did not touch Amadeo, but he had an obsession with young boys. He treats Amadeo well. But after a while, he finally begins grooming Amadeo into a sexual and romantic relationship. Amadeo calls him maestro. 5.content:
In 1556, the Roman coven sent Armand to lead the shambolic Paris coven called the Children of Darkness. They lived in squalor, hunted in shame, all in strict obedience to medieval law put in place to protect them from humanity. He ruled over the coven in Paris for 239 years, when one random night, one year after Lestat's transformation, he arrives to Paris - where Armand could feel Lestat's presence and follows it to a theater, where he senses that Lestat was sired by one of Armand's deserters, Magnus. There, Lestat was close to breaking the fourth of the Great laws: "No vampire shall ever reveal his true nature to a mortal and let that mortal live," and yet there he was prancing and preening in front of 500 mortals a night. Armand telepathically tells Lestat to come with him, but Lestat rejects his offer. A few weeks later, he directly confronts Lestat, using his abilities to overpower him and take his mortal lover Nicolas as leverage. As expected, Lestat follows Armand back to his lair, where he exposes to the coven that Armand has been lying to them and that a better life awaits, resulting in the coven abandoning Armand.

No one has painted me in over 400 years.

6.content:
With nothing left, the only thing keeping Armand from the fire are the old rituals. It is then that he is joined by Lestat, who wants to learn Armand's powers and who has turned Nicolas into a vampire but whose mind is rejecting the Dark Gift. Lestat then feeds from Armand's arm before inviting him to attend his next show, where not only the coven awaits, but Lestat explains to Armand how they can use the theater as a cover. Armand and Lestat proceeded to grow close over time, however, their relationship ends abruptly when Lestat seemingly disappears one day. Flash forward to 20th century Paris, and now Armand is falling for Louis and is hoping to convince him to join the coven, though Louis refuses. After finally getting Louis to confess to killing Lestat, Louis goes into a frenzy and viciously kills a man in the park, drawing attention to the coven, who look to Armand to do what needs to be done. However, instead of killing Louis, he kisses him after walking him home.

7.content:
Armand approaches Louis for the first time in a park known for gay hookups five months after he and Claudia arrive in Paris. He assures Louis that he means him no harm and invites him to the ThÃ©Ã¢tre des Vampires. After the show, Armand introduces Louis and Claudia to the rest of the coven, at which point, they discover that it was cofounded by Lestat. One month later, Armand invites the two of them to join the coven on a hunt. They arrive at the De LaCroix estate, where the coven feasts upon the guests inside, whilst Armand and Louis take outside. Armand mentions that Claudia is particularly skilled at blocking her thoughts, but Louis must work harder on that, as he felt some trepidation when Lestat's name was uttered. Louis feigns ignorance, but Armand is aware that he's hiding something and will wait until Louis is ready to share what that something is, but the coven can be volatile and unforgiving when lied to, so he urges Louis to shut his mind down if he hears Lestat's name again. He also tells Louis to never visit Lestat's law firm again. That sort of inquiry can open all sorts of trouble. Louis and Armand are then joined by the rest of the coven.Armand accosts Claudia for her lack luster performance, but she's grown tired of performing, as have some of the other coven members, who come to her defense, namely Santiago, who questions Armand for disciplining Claudia but allowing Louis to run wild, leaving many of them to wonder if he and Louis are companions. Armand says yes, but Louis says no, leading to a deeper conversation between the two regarding the nature of their relationship. However, "companions" isn't necessarily the word Louis would use to describe them. The following night, Armand takes Louis to an art gallery and shares his life story, how he was sold him into slavery, tortured at a brothel, and was later rescued from a brothel when he was 15 by his maker Marius De Romanus. After putting both Claudia and Santiago in their place, Armand meets with Louis in the park, where he expresses his concern of a nearing mutiny. Louis advises Armand to throw Santiago a bone, make him feel as though he's Armand's heir apparent. He'll overplay his hand, and everyone will see him for what he is. When they know they have no alternative, they'll beg for Armand back, and that's when he'll decide if he wants to go back or something else. Armand says that he wants Louis more than anything in the world. "You sure about that, Arun," Louis asks. "Yes, Maitre," Armand replies.Armand takes Louis' advice by feeding Santiago his own ego back to him and smothering mutiny with praise. However, unbeknownst to him, Santiago is conspiring behind his back. After refusing to turn Madeleine into a vampire at Louis and Claudia's behest, Armand is approached by the coven and given two options. They have learned that Louis and Claudia tried to kill Lestat. They instruct him to set a trap for Louis and Claudia. Although reluctant, Armand agrees to do so, meeting with Louis, Claudia, and Madeleine at a club, where Santiago and the rest of the coven grab them and bring them back to the theater for trial. Armand watches helplessly from one of the theater boxes as Louis, Claudia, and Madeleine are tried for their crimes. When it finally comes time for sentencing, all three of them are found guilty. Claudia and Madeleine are sentenced to death, burned alive. Whilst Louis, through Armand's intervention, as he uses his power to mind control the jury, is banished, placed in a coffin and buried with the rest of their damned. Armand is exposed. Armand is demoted and ridiculed after Santiago suspects he rigged the audience to spare Louis' life. He makes certain Armand will not forget his insubordination as part of his penance. In spite of this, Armand devises a plan to free Louis, doing so as everyone slept. However, rather than flee Paris as Armand hoped he would, Louis enacts his revenge, warning Armand not be at the theater tomorrow night at curfew, as that's when Louis sneaks in and sets the coven ablaze. After killing the lot of them, Armand and Louis convene at the apartment, where Armand comes clean to Louis about his dishonesty. Armand promises to spend his life trying to make it up to Louis, but Louis says he can never make it up. That night, they track down Lestat to Magnus' lair but ultimately leave him unharmed, at least physically. Despite his betrayal, Louis and Armand spend the next 77 years together, traveling the world, until present day.

8.content:
When Louis does not return home by sunrise, Armand goes over to the apartment to find him feeding on Molloy. Armand scolds Louis for his recklessness, for making another mess that Armand has to clean up. Louis exclaims that Armand is boring and dull, adding that the 10 hours he spent with Molloy were more exciting and fascinating than decades with Armand, who begins to mock Louis and his self-hatred. Armand expresses true frustration with Louis for saying Lestat's name, which went unuttered in their home for 23 years until last night. Upset, Louis rushes to the roof and into the sunlight in an attempt to kill himself, but Armand intervenes and pulls him back inside, though Louis is severely injured, and his skin is charred. With Louis incapacitated, Armand turns his attention to Molloy, questioning what exactly makes him so fascinating to Louis, but it remains a mystery to him. So he returns to Louis, and while putting him in his coffin, he says that he believes Louis is still chasing after Lestat. And if that's the case, Armand is prepared to part ways. But before doing so, he reveals that he knows where Lestat is and telepathically calls out to him, but Armand cuts it short when Lestat begins to express his love for Louis. Louis insists he only loves Armand, who decides to stay, intent on cleaning up Louis' mess by killing Molloy. Louis instructs him to leave the boy alive.
